item.title: Microaggression
item.description: Microaggression “indirect, subtle, or unintentional discrimination against members of a marginalized group.” was coined by Chester M. Pierce, a Harvard University psychiatrist

item.title: Ableism
item.description: Ableism Discrimination in favour of able-bodied people. Ableism is rampant throughout our society, devaluing and discriminating against people with physical, intellectual, or psychiatric disabilities.

item.title: equity and equality
item.description: Equity means giving people what they need to achieve fair outcomes. Equality means giving everyone the same resources and opportunities regardless of their differences.

item.title: Narcissism of Small Differences
item.description: in psychoanalysis, the narcissism of small differences is the idea that the more a relationship or community shares commonalities, the more likely the people in it are to engage in interpersonal feuds and mutual ridicule because of hypersensitivity to minor differences perceived in each other

item.title: Feminism
item.description: Feminism A social and political movement that advocates for the equality of all genders in all aspects of life, such as education, work, health, rights, and representation.

item.title: Gender
item.description: Gender A term that refers to the social and cultural aspects of being a man, a woman, or another gender. Gender is different from sex, which is based on biological characteristics such as chromosomes, hormones, and genitals.

item.title: Privilege
item.description: Privilege A term that refers to the advantages or benefits that some groups of people have over others in society, often due to their social identity or background.

item.title: Social Psychology
item.description: Definition scientific study that explains how the presence of others people, whether real, imaginary, or implied affects our thinking and behaviour - [[Gordon Allport]] 🔧!

item.title: Broken windows theory
item.description: theory was introduced in a 1982 article by social scientists James Q. Wilson and George L. Kelling the broken windows theory states that visible signs of crime, anti-social behaviour and civil disorder create an urban environment that encourages further crime and disorder, including serious crimes.

item.title: Clay Shirky
item.description: Clay Shirky (born 1964) is an American writer, consultant and teacher on the social and economic effects of Internet technologies and journalism.

item.title: Love, Internet Style
item.description: Video Noted Internet thinker and author [[Clay Shirky]] delivered one of the opening “provocations” at Supernova 2007. Using a 1300-year-old Japanese shrine as a metaphor, Clay explained how the New Network changes the basic dynamics of business and collective creativity.

item.title: anthroposemiotics
item.description: field of study dedicated to understanding how humans communicate The evolution of human communication took place over a long period of time from simple hand gestures to the use of spoken language

item.title: Campbell's Law
item.description: a social science principle that states that when a metric is used as a target or indicator of performance, it tends to lose its validity and distort the system it is supposed to measure.

item.title: mass communication
item.description: process of imparting and exchanging information through mass media to large population segments. It utilizes various forms of media as technology has made the dissemination of information more efficient.

item.title: streisand effect
item.description: The Streisand effect is a phenomenon in which attempts to hide, remove, or censor information can lead to the unintended consequence of increasing awareness of that information.

item.title: Wiio's Laws
item.description: a set of humorous aphorisms that describe how communication often fails or leads to misunderstanding named after Osmo Wiio, a Finnish professor and politician, who formulated them in 1978.

item.title: Argument to Moderation
item.description: logical fallacy that assumes that the truth is always a compromise between two opposite positions. It is also known as false compromise, argument from middle ground, or the golden mean fallacy.

item.title: Tragedy of Commons
item.description: situation where people use a shared resource (such as land, water, air, etc.) without considering the impact on others or the future.

item.title: Behaviour
item.description: broad definition - any action of an organism that changes its relationship to its environment. Behavior provides outputs from the organism to the environment.

item.title: Communication
item.description: Communication is a two-way process where information is exchanged or passed from one person to another person. The word is derived from ‘communicare’ which means to impart.
